conversation.text: Hi! What can I do for you?
I want to learn how to cook!
Sure. Do you want to learn how to make spaghetti with meatballs?
Yes! I love Italian food!
Let's get started. First, you need to whip eggs in a bowl. Then add salt and whatever seasonings you like.
evidence: Whip the eggs in a small bowl with a teaspoon of salt and your choice of seasonings.

conversation.text: Do you have any seasonings that you recommend?
You can try 1 adobo chili mixture.
Oh, I bet that would be tasty. What do I do next?
Dump the ground meat into a bowl. You can mix up things such as beef, lamb and veal if you want to.
evidence: Choose your ground meat and dump it into a big bowl.

conversation.text: How much should I be using?
It depends on your preference.
Ok, I guess if I want more meatballs use more meat!
Yes! Shall we move on?
Yes, I'm ready to move on.
Then add egg, Parmesan and bread crumbs to your mix and blend everything.
evidence: Pour the egg, Parmesan, and bread crumbs in and mix thoroughly with your hands.
, a stiff spatula or wooden spoon

conversation.text: Are there any measurements? I have no idea how much I should be using.
How many meatballs do you plan to make?
I am cooking for 2, so I'd like about 10.
You can use one egg, 1 cup (8 oz) bread crumbs and 1/2 cup (4 oz) grated Parmesan cheese.
Perfect. So what do I do after I have that all mixed together?
Then prepare to roll the meat into 1-inch balls.
evidence: Roll the meat into 1-inch (2.5 cm) balls.

conversation.text: Okay, and then how long do I have to cook them for?
It depends on your way of cooking. Do you want to fry or bake meatballs?
I would prefer to bake them. So much less mess!
Cool! You may want to bake them for 20-30 minutes at 350F. And don't forget to turn the meatballs during cooking.
evidence: bake meatballs for 20-30 min at 350F (175C), turning once or twice.

conversation.text: Great. And is there any other prep work I can do while the meatballs are cooking?
Just remember to check meatballs regularly and once they're finished, crank the heat to high or put them in the broiler.
evidence: crank the heat to high or put them in the broiler

conversation.text: Perfect. Should I start the pasta now?
Yes, you can add meatballs to your pasta now and then you're done.
How long should I cook my pasta for?
Sorry, I don't know. But I guess it's around 10 minutes. As long as the pasta gets soft, you are good to go.
Okay, I guess I will just see how it feels after 10 minutes!
No problem. Is there something else I can help?
No thank you for your help! Can't wait to taste this!
Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.

recipe.title: How to Make Spaghetti With Meatballs

procedure.summary: Whip the eggs in a small bowl with a teaspoon of salt and your choice of seasonings.
procedure.description:
Use a fork to beat the eggs, as if you were about to scramble them. Then add some salt and get to work seasoning to your heart's content. You can either make up your own seasoning or use one of the following mixes:
1 tablespoon (15ml) of your favorite bottle of "Italian" seasoning. Note -- check if it already has salt in it before adding separately. 1/2 teaspoon (7ml) oregano, garlic and onion powder, cracked red pepper, rosemary, and/or thyme
1 packet powdered onion or mushroom soup mix. 1 Adobo chili mixture or spice packet, with salt.

procedure.summary: Choose your ground meat and dump it into a big bowl.
procedure.description: Classically, meatballs are made from hamburger meat. But mixing things up, like the lovely Italian trio of beef, lamb, and veal, will lead to spectacular meatballs with little extra work.

procedure.summary: Pour the egg, Parmesan, and bread crumbs in and mix thoroughly with your hands.
procedure.description: Plunge your hands in and really squeeze to mix everything up. If you're squeamish, a stiff spatula or wooden spoon will work as well. Just make sure that everything is evenly blended and you have a wet, seasoned pile of meat when done. If desired, add the small diced onion here as well. Onion, when cooked, is a savory-sweet complement to the meat. Once it looks well mixed, you can stop. Extra mixing isn't helpful, and the more you mix the meat, the tougher it gets.

procedure.summary: Roll the meat into 1-inch (2.5 cm) balls.
procedure.description: You can make any size you want, but 1" balls tend to brown nicely on the outside while cooking quickly enough on the inside. Grab a small pinch of meat and roll it between your palms to get nice round meatballs. If you make larger meatballs, you may need to cook them a little longer, lowering the heat to prevent burning. Smaller balls can dry out if cooked too long. They must hit high heat, brown, and then come off quickly before over-cooking..

procedure.summary: Fry the meatballs on the stovetop over medium heat until browned on all sides.
procedure.description: Use a little bit of oil and rotate the meatballs every few minutes until browned and cooked. If the outsides are done, but the insides are still soft, lower the heat and let them cook for an extra 2-3 minutes. For the best meatballs, let them cook in a 1/2" (1-2 cm) of red sauce after they've browned -- they'll soak up some of the flavor and liquid to stay tender. A slow-cooker filled with sauce and meatballs can accomplish the same thing for beautifully rich, slow-cooked meatballs. To make them, add the sauce and meatballs to the cooker and cook on low heat for 6-8 hours.

procedure.summary: Alternatively, bake meatballs for 20-30 min at 350F (175C), turning once or twice.
procedure.description: Roasted meatballs bring out a rich, crisp flavor and texture, and create far less mess than stovetop cooking. Your biggest worry in the oven is drying out -- be sure to check the smaller balls regularly and take them out as soon as they are cooked all the way through. Once they are just about finished, crank the heat to high or put them in the broiler for 1 minute to get a wonderful brown crust on the tops.
